data.abstract: <jats:p>Members of the family <jats:italic>Secoviridae</jats:italic> are non-enveloped plant viruses with mono- or bipartite linear positive-sense ssRNA genomes with a combined genome of 9 to 13.7 kb and icosahedral particles 25–30 nm in diameter. They are related to picornaviruses and are members of the order <jats:italic>Picornavirales</jats:italic>. Genera in the family are distinguished by the host range, vector, genomic features and phylogeny of the member viruses. Most members infect dicotyledonous plants, and many cause serious disease epidemics. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) report on the family <jats:italic>Secoviridae</jats:italic>, which is available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.ictv.global/report/secoviridae" xlink:type="simple">ictv.global/report/secoviridae</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Secoviridae 2022

data.abstract: <jats:p>The family <jats:italic>Solemoviridae</jats:italic> includes viruses with icosahedral particles (26–34 nm in diameter) assembled on <jats:italic>T</jats:italic>=3 symmetry with a 4–6 kb positive-sense, monopartite, polycistronic RNA genome. Transmission of members of the genera <jats:italic>Sobemovirus</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Polemovirus</jats:italic> occurs via mechanical wounding, vegetative propagation, insect vectors or abiotically through soil; members of the genera <jats:italic>Polerovirus</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Enamovirus</jats:italic> are transmitted by specific aphids. Most solemoviruses have a narrow host range. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) Report on the family <jats:italic>Solemoviridae</jats:italic>, which is available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://www.ictv.global/report/solemoviridae" xlink:type="simple">ictv.global/report/solemoviridae</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Solemoviridae 2021

data.abstract: <jats:p>Members of the family <jats:italic>Plectroviridae</jats:italic> produce particles that are non-enveloped rigid rods (70–280×10–16 nm). The supercoiled, circular, single-stranded DNA genome of about 4.5–8.3 kb, encodes 4–13 proteins. Viruses of this family infect cell wall-less bacteria, adsorbing to the bacterial surface, replicating their DNA by a rolling-circle mechanism or transposition, and releasing progeny from cells by extrusion, without killing the host. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) Report on the family <jats:italic>Plectroviridae</jats:italic> which is available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.ictv.global/report/plectroviridae" xlink:type="simple">ictv.global/report/plectroviridae</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Plectroviridae

data.abstract:
<jats:p>
                  <jats:italic>Ovaliviridae</jats:italic> is a family of enveloped viruses with a linear dsDNA genome. The virions are ellipsoidal, and contain a multi-layered spool-like capsid. The viral genome is presumably replicated through protein priming by a putative DNA polymerase encoded by the virus. Progeny virions are released through hexagonal openings resulting from the rupture of virus-associated pyramids formed on the surface of infected cells. The only known host is a hyperthermophilic archaeon of the genus <jats:italic>
                     <jats:named-content content-type="genus">
                        <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://doi.org/10.1601/nm.66" xlink:type="simple">Sulfolobus</jats:ext-link>
                     </jats:named-content>
                  </jats:italic>. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) Report on the family <jats:italic>Ovaliviridae,</jats:italic> which is available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://www.ictv.global/report/ovaliviridae" xlink:type="simple">ictv.global/report/ovaliviridae</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Ovaliviridae

data.abstract: <jats:p>The <jats:italic>Corticoviridae</jats:italic> is a family of icosahedral, internal-membrane-containing viruses with double-stranded circular DNA genomes of approximately 10 kb. Only one species, <jats:italic>Pseudoalteromonas virus PM2</jats:italic>, has been recognized. Pseudoalteromonas virus PM2 infects Gram-negative bacteria and was isolated from seawater in 1968. Pseudoalteromonas virus PM2 is the first bacterial virus in which the presence of lipids in the virion has been demonstrated. Viral lipids are acquired selectively during virion assembly from the host cytoplasmic membrane. The outer protein capsid is an icosahedron with a pseudo <jats:italic>T</jats:italic>=21 symmetry. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) Report on the taxonomy of the <jats:italic>Corticoviridae</jats:italic>, which is available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.ictv.global/report/corticoviridae">www.ictv.global/report/corticoviridae</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Corticoviridae

data.abstract: <jats:p>The family <jats:italic>Matonaviridae</jats:italic> comprises enveloped viruses with positive-sense RNA genomes of 9.6–10 kb. The genus <jats:italic>Rubivirus</jats:italic> includes rubella virus (species <jats:italic>Rubivirus rubellae</jats:italic>) infecting humans, ruhugu virus (species <jats:italic>Rubivirus ruteetense</jats:italic>) infecting bats and rustrela virus (species <jats:italic>Rubivirus strelense</jats:italic>) infecting rodents and zoo animals. Rubella virus is spread via droplets. Postnatal infection leads to benign disease with rash and fever. Infection of seronegative women with rubella virus during the first trimester of pregnancy will often result in severe foetal malformations, known as congenital rubella syndrome. Vaccines are globally available. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) Report on the family <jats:italic>Matonaviridae,</jats:italic> which is available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://www.ictv.global/report/matonaviridae" xlink:type="simple">ictv.global/report/matonaviridae</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Matonaviridae 2022

data.abstract: <jats:p>Typical members of the family <jats:italic>Mymonaviridae</jats:italic> produce filamentous, enveloped virions containing a single molecule of linear, negative-sense RNA of about about 10 kb, but some may not produce any virions. The family includes several genera, some with multiple species. Mymonavirids usually infect filamentous fungi, but a few have been identified associated with insects, oomycetes or plants. At least one virus, Sclerotinia sclerotiorum negative-stranded RNA virus 1, induces hypovirulence in its fungal host. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) Report on the family <jats:italic>Mymonaviridae</jats:italic>, which is available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://ictv.global/report/mymonaviridae" xlink:type="simple">ictv.global/report/mymonaviridae</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Mymonaviridae 2022

data.abstract: <jats:p>Members of the family <jats:italic>Polymycoviridae</jats:italic> are small viruses with multi-segmented and non-conventionally encapsidated double-stranded (ds) RNA genomes. Typically, polymycoviruses have four genomic segments, although some have up to eight. The genus <jats:italic>Polymycovirus</jats:italic> includes several species whose members infect fungi (ascomycetes and basidiomycetes), and oomycetes, altering host morphology, sporulation, growth and virulence. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) Report on the family <jats:italic>Polymycoviridae,</jats:italic> which is available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://www.ictv.global/report/polymycoviridae" xlink:type="simple">ictv.global/report/polymycoviridae</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Polymycoviridae 2022
